Mothers Day is a Hard one ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

When does motherhood truly begin? Is it the moment you see two pink lines on a test, the day you feel that first flutter of movement, or the moment you hold your baby for the first time? For many, the answer is simple. But for women like me, who have lost countless pregnancies but cherished every moment of hope and excitement, the question is far more complex.

Each time I found out I was pregnant, I believed‚Äîwholeheartedly‚Äîthat this was the one. That this time, my dreams of becoming a mum would come true. And every time, that dream was taken away. Yet despite the heartbreak, I never lost the joy of those early moments. I never stopped feeling the privilege of even having that fleeting connection. There are so many women who don‚Äôt even get to experience that, and for that, I am truly blessed.

Society often sees women without children as having an easier ride. I hear it all the time‚Äî‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay for her, she doesn‚Äôt have kids.‚Äù But what people don‚Äôt consider is what some of us would give not to be in that position. What it feels like to have the deep longing for a child, only to have that dream slip away time and time again.

I may not have children to hold, but in those moments of joy, expectation, and love, I felt like a mum. Even if just for a little while. And maybe, just maybe, that‚Äôs enough to say I was one. | 65 comments on LinkedIn
